Article Text:
As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning'.

Q: What is career cushioning?

Q: Why is career cushioning important?

Q: How can I start career cushioning?

Q: What are some examples of career cushioning?

Q: Is career cushioning only for people in certain industries?

NEW DELHI: Microsoft Corp is reportedly planning to cut thousands of jobs, with some roles expected to be eliminated in the human resources and engineering divisions, according to media reports on Tuesday.This move follows similar job cuts announced by other tech companies, such as Amazon, Meta Platforms , Twitter, Google , Salesforce and a host of other corporations.These job cuts are being attributed to slowing demand and a worsening global economic outlook. The move by Microsoft indicates that the tech sector may continue to shed jobs in the coming months.As job cuts continue to rise in tech and various other industries, some employees are choosing to proactively seek out new job opportunities while still employed. This strategy, referred to as " career cushioning ". Here is all you need to know on 'career cushioning'A: Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable and resilient to job loss or industry changes. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.A: Career cushioning can help provide a sense of security and confidence in uncertain job markets and can also open up new opportunities for career advancement. It can also help you be better prepared if you do lose your job, making it easier to find new employment.A: There are several ways to begin career cushioning, such as:Building a diverse skill set through continuing education or volunteer workNetworking with professionals in your industry and other industriesBuilding a personal brand through social media and professional online presenceSaving money for unexpected career changes or job loss.A: Some examples of career cushioning include:-A software developer taking on freelance web design projects to gain experience in user interface design.-A marketing professional starting a blog to gain experience in content creation.-A sales representative taking on additional responsibilities in product development to gain experience in product management.A: No, career cushioning is applicable for people in any industry. It's about being proactive in preparing for potential changes in your career, regardless of the industry you're in.A: It's a good idea to review your career cushioning efforts regularly, perhaps once or twice a year. This will allow you to assess your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plans. Additionally, keeping an eye on the job market and industry trends can help you anticipate and prepare for any potential changes in your field.A: You can gauge the effectiveness of your career cushioning efforts by monitoring your progress in gaining new skills and experiences, as well as the feedback you receive from your professional network and potential employers. Additionally, you may find that you are better able to adapt to changes in your industry, or that you have more opportunities available to you.A: The amount of time you should dedicate to career cushioning will depend on your individual goals and circumstances, however it's important to balance the time you spend career cushioning with your other responsibilities. A good rule of thumb is to spend some time each week or month working on career cushioning activities, but not to the point that it negatively impacts other areas of your life.
Article Summary: As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning' Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.

Article Text:
Northern lights may drift across US skies this week: Know where to spot them

Northern skies do not usually proclaim themselves. Most nights are calm, even when something faraway moves above the earth. This week is little different. A pulse of solar activity is travelling across Earth's magnetic field, and this change could be enough to bring the northern lights into view in portions of the United States. It is not guaranteed, and it will not appear the same everywhere. Some people may notice a gentle tint on the horizon, while others may see nothing. However, for a brief period in early January, the odds shift somewhat. Space weather forecasters and sky watchers are keeping a tight eye on the darkness, hoping it may reveal something unexpected rather than being empty for once during the harshest stretch of winter evenings.The strongest chances sit far north, as they usually do. Alaska remains the most reliable place, almost separate from the rest of the map when it comes to aurora watching. Parts of:These areas lie closer to where Earth‚Äôs magnetic field funnels charged particles into the atmosphere. NOAA forecasts suggest activity could peak overnight between January 8 and January 9, though timing often slips by hours. In these states, the lights may form brighter arcs or slow-moving curtains rather than faint smudges.Even then, nothing is promised. Auroras are known for appearing briefly and fading without warning.States a little below the usual aurora belt are not entirely out of luck. Minnesota, Michigan, and Maine often sit on the edge during moderate geomagnetic storms, and this week could be another of those moments. The display in these places is usually subtle. Colour may appear washed out, sometimes closer to grey than green. It often stays low in the northern sky, easy to mistake for a cloud or distant glow. Wyoming, Vermont, New Hampshire, and parts of New York fall into a similar category. For viewers there, seeing the aurora often depends on patience and expectations. Many who do catch it only realise later when photos reveal more than the eye noticed at the time.The trigger comes from the Sun, though not in a dramatic, cinematic way. A coronal mass ejection has sent a stream of charged particles outward, interacting with a co rotating interaction region already moving through space. Together, they disturb Earth‚Äôs magnetic field just enough to produce a G1-level geomagnetic storm. That rating is considered minor, but minor does not mean invisible. It simply means effects are more local and less intense. Space weather remains difficult to predict with precision. Solar wind speed, density, and direction can all shift suddenly. Forecasts improve as the storm arrives, but uncertainty never fully disappears.Even the strongest aurora means little under thick cloud. Cloud cover remains the biggest reason people miss these events, regardless of solar activity. Clear skies matter more than most other factors. Light pollution is the next obstacle. Urban lighting can wash out faint auroras entirely, especially in southern locations. Rural areas, coastal stretches, and dark sky parks offer better odds. Many experienced observers suggest letting your eyes adjust and avoiding phone screens for a while. Cameras often see more than humans do, especially in low light modes. Sometimes the night still looks empty. Sometimes it does not. That uncertainty is part of the pull.
Article Summary: A pulse of solar activity is travelling across Earth's magnetic field. This change could be enough to bring the northern lights into view in portions of the United States. It is not guaranteed, and it will not appear the same everywhere. NOAA forecasts suggest activity could peak overnight between January 8 and January 9.

The announcement came via the monorail‚Äôs official channels, with operators confirming that station maintenance is the reason behind the service stoppage. While riders and commuters await updates, alternative transport like taxis, buses and private vehicles have become the de facto way to traverse the popular destination.The Palm Monorail, which first opened in April 2009 and runs approximately 5.45 km across the famed Palm Jumeirah to Atlantis Aquaventure Resort, has served residents, hotel guests and visitors for over 16 years. Designed as a scenic and efficient link across the inland portion of the man-made island, it features four stations and was operated by UK-based transport firm Serco.This suspension marks one of the most significant disruptions to the fleet since its launch and critically, there is currently no timeline for service resumption. While the monorail has historically played a niche role in the city‚Äôs broader transit ecosystem (with other heavy traffic handled by road vehicles and the Dubai Metro), it has nonetheless been a memorable part of the Palm experience, often recommended by guides and included in visitor itineraries.According to official statements and travel reports, the shutdown is due to ongoing station maintenance across the monorail network. The operators emphasised that this maintenance is vital to ensure long-term efficiency and safety. It is a necessity for infrastructure nearing two decades of operation.However, there are no published details about the scope, duration or specific technical issues being addressed and a reopening date has not been announced. The lack of a firm timeline has caught many by surprise, including frequent riders and tourists planning visits during Dubai‚Äôs peak travel months.For tourists, the monorail was not only functional but scenic and offered elevated views of the Palm trunk, fronds and skyline beyond. Its absence removes one of the region‚Äôs most visually distinctive transport experiences, with many visitors now questioning whether a Palm Jumeirah visit will feel less complete without it.Dubai‚Äôs transport ecosystem continues to accommodate tens of thousands of daily commuters via roads, ferries, the Dubai Metro and buses, but the monorail‚Äôs suspension, especially without a reopening timeline, has created a sense of uncertainty for travel planners and local enthusiasts alike. Unlike typical ride or track refurbishments in theme parks or transit systems worldwide, where scheduled closures often come with reopening forecasts, Dubai‚Äôs monorail maintenance appears to be in a more fluid or potentially extensive phase.For instance, other major attractions that undergo periodic maintenance (such as aerial tramways elsewhere) often announce specific closure windows and reopening dates well in advance. The Palm Springs Aerial Tramway in California, for example, closed for its annual maintenance and clearly communicated both start and reparative timelines months before reopening.By contrast, the Palm Monorail closure has only been explained as a maintenance necessity, with no estimated timeline distributed so far. It is a situation that could hint at deeper or more unpredictable engineering work underway. There are a few possible scenarios for the Palm Monorail‚Äôs future:While operators have not issued such updates, Dubai‚Äôs dynamic urban growth suggests that transport infrastructure will continue to evolve, and the monorail, as a symbolic and strategic asset, may yet be refashioned to play a renewed role once technical work is complete.With Dubai‚Äôs Palm Monorail suspended indefinitely for maintenance, residents and visitors heading to Palm Jumeirah will need to rely on alternative transport options. Here‚Äôs a simple guide to the fastest, easiest and most practical ways to move around the Palm while the monorail remains out of service.Though these options maintain mobility, riders have noted longer transit times, especially during rush hours or high-season tourism peaks. Some social media users have expressed frustration at the lack of clarity about when the monorail might return, underscoring how the system is valued both as transport and as a leisure experience.For visitors planning Dubai itineraries in early 2026, the monorail closure means:The Palm Monorail, a once-celebrated urban transport highlight, is out of service for essential maintenance with no reopening date yet. The closure underscores both Dubai‚Äôs commitment to long-term safety and the challenges of sustaining ageing transport systems in a rapidly growing city.Though seemingly minor in the grand scheme of Dubai‚Äôs transport network, the monorail‚Äôs indefinite suspension stands as a reminder that iconic infrastructure sometimes needs serious upkeep and that even world-class cities must balance maintenance demands with high expectations from residents and visitors alike. While the Palm Monorail remains closed with no reopening date announced, Palm Jumeirah is still fully accessible.Taxis and buses are currently the most reliable alternatives, while tram links and hotel shuttles help bridge the gap. With a bit of planning, getting around the Palm remains smooth, even without its iconic monorail.

Article Title: UAE‚Äôs cloud seeding secret: How salt, AI, drones are used to make it rain in desert
Article Text:
How Does It Rain in the Desert? The UAE‚Äôs Cloud-Seeding Secret Explained

Cloud seeding is not magic but meteorology, planes, salt and cloud chemistry

Why It Rains in the UAE: Planes, AI and the Science of Desert Rain

From Salt to Satellites: How the UAE Is Hacking the Sky to Make It Rain

Ground-based generators: In mountainous areas, ground stations release seeding materials into rising winds that carry them up into clouds.

Is cloud seeding working? What the data says



AI, Aircraft and Salt Crystals: How the UAE Is Boosting Rainfall

Cloud seeding myths, misunderstandings and real weather



How cloud seeding works

Bottom line







Even if you have never been to a desert, you would have seen it on screens, how rain bursts despite arid desert sun but in the UAE, rain does not just happen by chance. Behind the scenes, scientists are actively nudging clouds to drop more water, using aircraft, salt crystals, artificial intelligence and some of the world‚Äôs most advanced weather-tech. Yes, there is a real-world rain machine in one of the planet‚Äôs driest regions.Welcome to the UAE‚Äôs cloud-seeding programme, a long-running national effort to enhance rainfall in a place that normally gets less than 100 mm of rain a year.The concept is simpler than it sounds. The UAE does not create rain from thin air, it enhances rain that might already be there. Scientists constantly scan the skies using sophisticated weather radars and 26 live camera feeds to spot developing cumulus clouds with potential.When conditions look right, they are ready to act. From meteorological radar data to real-time cloud analysis, researchers identify the best moments and places to intervene, no crystal balls required.When suitable clouds form, specially equipped aircraft take to the skies. Pilots fly into the updrafts, rising currents of air within convective clouds and deploy seeding agents like microscopic salt crystals mixed with magnesium, sodium chloride and potassium chloride.These tiny particles act as condensation nuclei, meaning that they attract and cluster water droplets within the cloud. As droplets grow larger and heavier, gravity finally pulls them down as rainfall instead of letting them evaporate in the dry desert air.In 2025 alone, the UAE reported 172 cloud-seeding flights, aiming to boost rain, not create weather from nothing.Think cloud seeding is stuck in the last century? The truth is that the UAE has invested in cutting-edge innovations -Together, these upgrades are pushing cloud-seeding into a more efficient ‚Äúrain-tech‚Äù arena rather than a simple aerial stunt.Studies and operational data suggest that cloud seeding can increase rainfall by roughly 10% to 25% under the right conditions and is significant when every extra drop counts. Some research even links cloud-seeded storms to larger volumes of water reaching the ground, with gains measured in hundreds of millions of cubic metres of usable water annually, a real lifeline in a region where water security is a top priority.Still, experts caution that cloud seeding is not a perfect rainmaker as it cannot produce rain unless clouds already have moisture and results can vary depending on atmospheric conditions. The UAE‚Äôs water challenges are real. Rapid urban growth and limited natural freshwater mean the country relies heavily on desalination plants, recycled water and cloud seeding to meet its needs.Cloud seeding is far more cost-effective than desalination for extra water as one flight costs around US $8,000 per hour, a bargain when compared to the energy and infrastructure required to turn seawater into drinking water. That is why the UAE has invested millions of dollars into research and technology, including local manufacturing of seed materials and international scientific partnerships.Despite its gains, cloud seeding sometimes gets blamed for extreme weather like the surprising flooding seen in parts of the Emirates. However, meteorologists are clear that cloud seeding cannot create storms out of nothing. Heavy rains during major weather events are natural phenomena that cloud seeding can neither trigger nor control.In social media discussions, some critics call cloud seeding ‚Äúscam technology‚Äù or blame it for unexpected rainfall but even sceptics acknowledge that the programme generally only enhances rain when clouds already exist. Cloud seeding in the UAE is not about controlling nature, it is about coaxing nature to give a little extra.As climate change increases weather unpredictability and water scarcity pressures mount, experts see rain enhancement as one valuable tool among many. Whether it is planes, drones, nano-powder or AI pilots, the UAE‚Äôs cloud-seeding programme is a fascinating blend of technology, meteorology and environmental strategy. It is a uniquely desert-born experiment in making the sky work for people.The UAE‚Äôs effort to ‚Äúmake it rain‚Äù is not science fiction, it is a real, high-tech programme combining radar, planes, salts, nano-materials and AI to enhance rainfall in one of the driest climates on Earth. While it has limitations, cloud seeding represents a creative response to water scarcity, one that other water-stressed regions are watching closely.

Scientists constantly scan the skies using sophisticated weather radars and 26 live camera feeds to spot developing cumulus clouds with potential. Pilots fly into the updrafts, rising currents of air within convective clouds and deploy seeding agents like microscopic salt crystals.

Article Title: Did Starmer impose a curfew in the UK? No, it's just a fake TikTok video
Article Text:
Keir Starmer

Coup In Britain? Starmer‚Äôs ‚ÄòOwn Cabinet Plots‚Äô His Downfall | ‚ÄòFull Bunker Mode‚Äô In No. 10





The 61-second video of UK PM Keir Starmer would be shocking, if it were true. "The UK is set to introduce a nationwide curfew, beginning at 11pm each night," he appears to say on one of thousands of TikTok videos of him posted in last six months. "Under the new rule, no one will be permitted to leave their home after 11pm without official authorisation."Starmer never made any such policy or announcement. But thanks to AI, the PM in the short video sounded eerily like the real one. The fake video attracted over 430,000 views and inspired similar posts on X and Facebook. That video, and other similar ones, appears to have been taken down by the Chinese-owned social media company, which officially prohibits "fake authoritative sources or crisis events, or falsely shows public figures in certain contexts. "But the clip was just one of 6,042 such videos, most featuring Starmer, identified by NewsGuard, a company that tracks online misinformation, between May and Dec. In a report, it said the videos were posted by accounts with names of fake, British-sounding news organisations like "BBB UK News" and "Daily Britain News." Together, the accounts had more than 1 million followers when the report was issued. "It consistently emulates Starmer," said Eva Maitland, senior analyst for Russian influence at NewsGuard."It produces false or baseless claims that look bad for the Starmer govt, and they're kind of created to create a strong response from people so that they'll click on it."Maitland said the videos do not appear to be part of a coordinated effort by foreign adversaries like Russia or the PM's domestic political opponents to damage him in the eyes of voters. Rather, she said, they are likely being created by content producers whose primary goal is to make money by making videos that go viral.The widespread adoption of easy-to-use AI video generation tools, like OpenAI's Sora, has dramatically increased the number of fake videos on TikTok and other social media platforms. The fake videos come at a particularly difficult time for the PM, who is already suffering from very low polling numbers. In one video, Starmer seems to announce new drivers licence laws that could strip many British people of their ability to drive legally in the country. Another video has Starmer's faked voice declaring that new rules will allow the authorities to access any British person's phone, along with its private data.In the immediate days after NewsGuard published its report on Dec 9, many of the videos were available on TikTok. By Dec 19, most appeared to have been removed from the platform. Howard said the use of AI in politics is increasing rapidly. "We know it's internationally pervasive now," he said. "Four of every five elections around the world now have AI-generated political junk that is unattributed and clearly misleading. "
Article Summary: Thousands of fake videos of UK PM Keir Starmer have been posted on TikTok. The videos were created by accounts with fake, British-sounding news organisations. NewsGuard, a company that tracks online misinformation, identified 6,042 such videos between May and Dec.

Article Title: Ask Dhirendra: 'How do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?'
Article Text:
The problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save. (AI image)

‚ÄúHow do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?‚Äù

What can you save today without breaking your life? How can you make that number grow every year?

Where does a typical salary go?

Some expenses are non-negotiable (rent, basic food, fees).

Some are negotiable but important (a modest phone, occasional eating out).

Some are pure leakage (unused subscriptions, impulsive orders, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even remember what this was‚Äù).

From spare change to serious money

Step up your SIP before you step up your lifestyle

First, add up your genuine essentials: rent/EMI, groceries, utilities, fees, basic transport.

Next, be realistic and add a modest amount for discretionary spending that you know you‚Äôll do anyway ‚Äì because you are human, not a robot.

See what is left. From that leftover, commit to a percentage ‚Äì even 10% of your take-home income ‚Äì as a non-negotiable saving and investing amount. Set up automatic transfers and SIPs for that right after your salary date.

If you have any queries for Dhirendra Kumar you can drop us an email at: toi.business@timesinternet.in

(Dhirendra Kumar is Founder and CEO of Value Research)

This is one of those questions that sounds technical, but is actually very emotional.On paper, it‚Äôs simple: income comes in, expenses go out, and whatever is left is ‚Äúsavings. In real life, income comes in, rent, EMIs, school fees, petrol, Swiggy, Zomato, sale on Myntra, birthday gifts, one sudden expense‚Ä¶ and at the end of the month, you look at your balance and say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start investing from next month. Pakka.‚ÄùNext month looks surprisingly similar.So let‚Äôs start with an honest admission: for most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough.At Value Research, whenever we look at this, we don‚Äôt begin with a number like ‚Äúyou must save 30%‚Äù. We start with a different idea: savings are not what is left after spending. Savings are what you decide first; spending adjusts after that if you flip this order, the maths ‚Äì and your behaviour ‚Äì changes completely.A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income to savings and investments. However, I also know that for many people today, 30% sounds like a bad joke. So instead of fighting over the ‚Äúideal‚Äù number, let‚Äôs work with two simpler questions:To answer the first question, you need to know where your money is actually going, not where you think it is going.For one or two months, track your expenses honestly ‚Äì not for Instagram, for yourself. You don‚Äôt need an app; even a simple notebook or spreadsheet works.Once you see your own pie chart, three things usually stand out:Your first ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù might simply be plugging two or three leaks. Even if that frees up only ‚Çπ2,000‚Äì‚Çπ3,000 a month, that is your starting SIP.Now let‚Äôs look at how ‚Äúsmall‚Äù that really is.When we run these numbers at Value Research in our retirement and goal calculators, the results are always the same: the gap between zero and small is far bigger than the gap between small and perfect.But what if your income truly is at the survival stage? There are people for whom even ‚Çπ2,000 is a luxury some months. If that‚Äôs your reality, you have two parallel jobs. One is to create a tiny habit ‚Äì even ‚Çπ500 or ‚Çπ1,000 a month into a recurring deposit or a conservative fund. The absolute amount is less important than the mental switch from ‚ÄúI‚Äôll save if anything is left‚Äù to ‚ÄúI will save something, and then I will live on the rest. ‚ÄùThe second job is to make sure that as your income grows, your lifestyle doesn‚Äôt expand at the same speed. This is where a lot of middle-class Indians quietly sabotage themselves. Every salary increase automatically becomes a better phone, nicer meals out, upgraded gadgets, and bigger car loans. The percentage saved stays the same, or sometimes even falls.A very powerful habit ‚Äì one we often build into plans at Value Research ‚Äì is the ‚Äústep-up‚Äù. Each year, when your salary goes up, you increase your SIPs and savings before you upgrade anything else.In many examples we‚Äôve run, the step-up strategy leads to a dramatically higher corpus at the end, without you ever feeling an acute ‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù in any single year. You just avoid letting every pay hike leak out into lifestyle.Now, how do you decide your own number?Here‚Äôs a simple approach:If that number feels tight, start a little lower and promise yourself one thing: every time your income goes up, your savings rate will go up faster than your spending.At Value Research, when we build long-term plans, we don‚Äôt assume people will suddenly start saving 40% from next month. We assume they will start somewhere realistic, and then we design step-ups. The rigour is in the process, not in some magical starting number.One last point. Many people postpone investing because they are embarrassed by how small their starting amount looks. Please don‚Äôt underestimate the psychological power of seeing a small, growing pile that you started and maintained. It changes how you think about yourself: from ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt save‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am someone who always saves something.‚Äù That identity is worth more than one extra dinner out.So how much should you save and invest when your income feels just about enough? The honest answer is: start with whatever you can without lying to yourself, protect that amount like you protect your rent, and then make sure it rises every time your income increases. The ‚Äúright‚Äù number is not what a formula says; it‚Äôs the number you will actually stick to for the next 20 years.The perfect percentage can wait. The first rupee cannot.
Article Summary: Dhirendra Kumar: For most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough. A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income.

When individuals open bank accounts, invest in mutual funds, or buy insurance, they are often asked to name a nominee.However, many people mistakenly assume that the nominee automatically inherits the assets. In reality, the nominee is not always the final recipient ‚Äî the ownership rights belong to the legal heir, reported ET.Understanding the distinction between these two is essential to ensure that your wealth is passed on to the intended beneficiaries.A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets.The nominee‚Äôs role is limited to holding and managing the assets until they are legally transferred to the rightful heirs.According to ET, the nominee cannot sell, trade, or make any transactional decisions about the assets.The account or policy owner can appoint anyone ‚Äî family, friends, or acquaintances ‚Äî as a nominee, though financial institutions often prefer close family members.In some cases, the nominee and the legal heir can be the same person, which helps in ensuring a smoother transfer of assets.The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away.To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will or other testamentary proof.If there is no will ‚Äî a situation known as dying intestate ‚Äî the heir is determined as per the country‚Äôs succession or personal laws, reported ET.While a nominee can initially access the assets, only the legal heir can claim them permanently or challenge ownership in court.Experts quoted by ET emphasise that having clarity on this difference helps avoid disputes and ensures that the savings reach the intended family members or beneficiaries.Therefore, it is advisable to regularly update both nominees and wills to align with one‚Äôs estate planning goals.

By visiting https://jeevanpramaan.gov.in, pensioners can submit their Digital Life Certificate using a computer, laptop, or smartphone equipped with a fingerprint or iris scanner.The system uses the Aadhaar platform to authenticate biometric details. Key components of hallmark on gold jewellery



Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.

A wide-ranging collection of Steve Jobs‚Äô childhood belongings and some of Apple‚Äôs earliest products has gone up for auction as the company approaches its 50th anniversary on April 1, 2026. Signed by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, the $500 cheque was made out to Howard Cantin, who designed the printed circuit board for the Apple-1 computer.
